awd_titl_txt: CRII: III:  Rare Event Prediction in Time Series
awd_abstract_narration:
Predicting rare events within a time series is a critical task in many real-world applications. Taking the healthcare industry as an example, it would be very useful to predict an influx in the number of patients that would overwhelm a hospital beyond its capacity. Without such capability, it could have negative consequences in the hospital’s ability to adequate health care. Rare event prediction in time series is a challenging problem due to the non-linear nature of rare events, the inability to capture their key information in the systematic components of the temporal data, and the data imbalance between rare and normal events. This project will result in a framework to address these challenges. With such a prediction framework, steps can be taken to ensure the affected population's readiness for such rare events. For instance, the application of the resulting technology will significantly improve readiness in the healthcare care industry. Furthermore, the resulting technology can be applied to other areas of societal interest.

This project studies the nature of rare events in time series and addresses the above-mentioned challenges with three technical aims. First, it is well known that sequence models such as recurrent neural networks can be used to capture both the temporal and non-linear nature of the data. Nevertheless, they have not been well studied for the problem of rare event prediction in time series. One goal of this project is to thoroughly study if sequence models can capture both the temporal and non-linear nature of the rare events to facilitate the prediction. Second, the key information of rare events can be hidden by the seasonal fluctuations in the time series. Another goal of this project is to study if time series decomposition that separates the seasonality can help the prediction of rare events. Finally, in terms of the data imbalance problem, traditional prediction models often treat normal and rare events equivalently, which can be harmful for the rare event prediction. This project will develop a new method based on the properties of rare events to emphasize their importance. Moreover, filters can be specifically designed to extract rare events better to reduce the effect from large amount of normal data. Both strategies have not been well studied for the rare event prediction in time series, which will be the third goal of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to predict rare events in time series with the application focus in the field of healthcare, especially on the early prediction of sepsis onset with a collaboration with ICU at UW Harborview Medical Center.

Intellectual Merits:

It is well known that sequence models such as recurrent neural networks can be used to capture both the temporal and non-linear nature of the data. Nevertheless, they were not well studied for the problem of rare event prediction in time series. In this project, we have observed that sequence models can capture both the temporal and non-linear nature of the rare events to facilitate the prediction compared to traditional methods. However, the severe imbalance makes the improvement marginal. Moreover, the key information of rare events can be hidden by the seasonal fluctuations in the time series. We have observed that time series decomposition that separates the seasonality can help the prediction of rare events. However, further improvement is needed.

Therefore, to better address the severe class imbalance problem, we then focused on the aim of developing new techniques for that. First, we found that a cost-adaptive loss function that emphasizes the loss on the rare event prediction can help significantly improve the performance. Second, our multi-subset approach to add a progressing probability of sepsis in the time series format can also help capture more patterns on the onset of rare events, and thus improve the performance of prediction. More importantly, due to the limited amount of sepsis observations in the data, directly doing classification between sepsis/not cannot capture the potential local variance of the sepsis data distribution well. We found that patient profile representation learning by uniquely identify patients' daily conditions can help preserve local variance, and then avoid the potential domination of non-sepsis patients during the classification. Recently, we have also observed that multi-modal large language models may contain substantial knowledge for rare events that may not appear in the observed clinical data, which can help significantly improve the performance of rare event prediction. Therefore, incorporating multiple modalities of data (e.g., vision, language, time series) will be very helpful for rare event prediction. Details of all these research findings can be observed in our publications or pending publications.

Broader Impacts:

From 2021-2024, this project involved four PhD students (two are female, one is first-generation African American), eleven MSc students (five of them are female), two undergrad students (one is female), and three high school students. Therefore, this project has encouraged K-12 students and underrepresented students in STEM. Most of the PhD students were directly supported by the funding on RA ship and/or tuition. In summary, these students have produced 5 master thesis and 4 capstones towards their masters' graduation. We have also published 5 papers on prestigious conferences (one pending publication), one technical report, and one submission under review. For these research outcomes, the students also had opportunities to do oral/poster presentations to seek feedback from peers and outstanding researchers. In summary, we have one poster to be conducted in Oct. 2024, one oral conducted by the student at BigData'23, one oral conducted at CSCE'23, two talks conducted at the school's research seminars, four posters presented at the school's research showcase. Therefore, through this project, all students have been trained on research procedures including but not limited to literature review, presentations, writing and so on. Moreover, they had the opportunity to communicate with our collaborator from UW Medicine through an interdisciplinary scenario for the benefit of their future career. More importantly, this collaboration with UW Medicine Harboview Center ICU will help doctors at ICU make more efficient and effective decisions on the treatment of patients, which is very important to provide early treatment and save lives of trauma patients. In addition, rare event prediction is a general problem happening in various domains, which will benefit the society in large.


Last Modified: 09/29/2024
Modified by: Juhua Hu
